Award.AwardTitle: Broadening Participation Research Grant: Applying the Performance Pyramid to STEM Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Lincoln University HBCU-UP Broadening participation Research in STEM Education project is entitled Applying the Performance Pyramid to STEM Education. The study proposes the use of a comprehensive theoretical model derived from performance evaluation in business settings to examine the support needs of underrepresented minority STEM students. The theoretical model is intended to explain the reasons why curricular innovations may or may not be effective. It will also guide curricular design by giving innovators the flexibility to develop programs that appear different from established programs but still bear the same foundational principles of performance success. The broad goals of the proposed project are to (1) improve the participation and success of African American students in STEM disciplines; (2) adapt a performance model to create measures to examine minority student support in STEM programs; and (3) broadly communicate the performance model, measures, and research findings through communication with local and national stakeholders.

The proposal outlines three studies that test the Performance Pyramid model of evaluating the foundations of differential engagement of ethnic groups in STEM disciplines. The first study will be a needs assessment to identify the level of perceived support available to African American STEM majors. The second and third studies will use the needs assessment data to design two innovative programs (Math2 and STEM Alliance) to increase support, learning, and persistence of African American STEM majors. The study will apply the Performance Pyramid support systems as a framework to determine the foundational reasons why African American students succeed in STEM disciplines. This can ultimately produce a viable model for assessing academic support systems for minority STEM students and increase retention.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the Applying the Performance Pyramid to STEM Education (APPS) project was to enhance the development of a competitive, diverse science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) workforce. The project accomplished this goal by: (1) improving the participation and success of students in STEM disciplines, (2) adapting a performance model to measure student support in STEM programs, and (3) broadly communicating the performance model, measures, and research findings through communication with local and national stakeholders. These outcomes were accomplished in a series of research studies which took place over three years. 

This project improved student participation in the STEM disciplines through a combination of teaching interventions and extracurricular activities aimed at STEM students. The grant supported formation of STEM Alliance, a student organization with a membership of over 150 students. STEM Alliance organized 10-25 educational and career activities for students per year. For example, STEM Alliance offered free GRE (Graduate Record Exam) preparation sessions to assist students with graduate school admission. Twenty students were additionally employed as teaching assistants and research assistants. These students gained valuable experience working with faculty mentors, speaking at professional meetings across the United States, and publishing research.  Research findings showed that students who participated in the grant felt greater support in the STEM disciplines. The institution also increased the proportion of STEM majors from 5% to 7% over the course of the grant. 

The project was guided by a performance model called the “Performance Pyramid.” The model specifies six support domains students need to be successful in STEM careers. One research study involved creating a survey instrument to measure student support in these six domains. After validating the survey instrument, researchers completed a needs assessment to evaluate the domains in which student support needed improvement. This allowed researchers to design course and extracurricular activities to meet student needs. Statistics and calculus courses were redesigned to focus on problem-solving activities. These courses continued to be taught according to the redesign after the funding period expired.

The performance model, measures, and research findings were broadly communicated over the course of the grant. The goal of dissemination was to share the tools and experiences of the project with other departments and organizations seeking to improve STEM education.  Students and faculty wrote five manuscripts based on the research, two of which were published in peer-reviewed journals (three additional manuscripts were under review at the time this report was submitted). Faculty members and students presented their research at 14 professional conferences. In addition, students and faculty members held 67 events on the campus of Lincoln University.
